title: Franz Haller
text:
Ferenc Haller, "count Haller von Hallerkeö" (24 March 1796 – 5 March 1875) was a Hungarian politician. He served as <a href="Ban%20%28title%29">ban</a> of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Croatia-Slavonia">Croatia-Slavonia</a> between 1842 and 1845 during the Croatian national revival and the <a href="Illyrian%20movement">Illyrian movement</a> in the 1830s and 1840s.
Haller was born in <a href="Kerel%C5%91szentp%C3%A1l">Kerelőszentpál</a>, <a href="Transylvania">Transylvania</a>, as a member of the Hungarian-Transylvanian branch of the <a href="Haller%20von%20Hallerstein">Haller von Hallerstein</a> family. He was promoted by emperor <a href="Franz%20Joseph">Franz Joseph</a> as ban on 16 June 1842 and was later promoted to lieutenant general. He took office on 18 October. Haller was brought in to carry on <a href="Magyarization">Magyarization</a> in <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>. In 1843, the use of the Illyrian name was banned. In large part due to the <a href="July%20victims">July victims</a> incident, in which thirteen protesters were killed in <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>, Haller resigned his post and continued his military career in the <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a>. Bishop <a href="Juraj%20Haulik">Juraj Haulik</a> became ban soon after.
In 1845 Haller donated 500 <a href="forint">forint</a> for building the <a href="Croatian%20National%20Theatre%20in%20Zagreb">Croatian National Theatre</a> in <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>.
